title: Danny Zayat found guilty of murdering ex-girlfriend Tatiana Dokhotaru | ABC NEWS
description: Sydney man Danny Zayat has been found guilty of murdering his former partner, 34-year-old Tatiana Dokhotaru, at their Liverpool apartment in 2023. Zayat denied having violent and abusive tendencies, insisting he left their apartment after an argument and found his ex-girlfriend dead the next day. But, the jury returned a guilty verdict after hearing two weeks of evidence that laid bare his behaviour in a volatile relationship. title: Grattan urges higher-density development incentives to ease housing market | ABC NEWS
description: A report from public policy think tank Grattan Institute has found that rents and house prices would ease if all capital are cities rezoned to allow higher-density housing. Report co-author Brendan Coates says the federal government should consider incentives for state-level reform to zoning laws that would unlock potential for more medium and high density development. title: Shein opens first worldwide permanent store in Paris | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The French government has suspended access to Chinese retailer Shein's online platform after days of controversy and protests over the sale of sex dolls with child-like features on its website. As Madeline Lo-Booth reports, the decision comes just hours after the fast-fashion retailer launched its first physical shopfront, inside one of Paris' most iconic department stores.   Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Leaders start arriving in Brazil for COP30 climate summit | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Global leaders are starting to arrive in Brazil for the United Nation's upcoming COP30 climate summit. With all eyes will be on the climate diplomacy that takes place, there will be two notable absences from the summit with US President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese not in attendance. ʻAlopi Latukefu is a social justice and climate advocate who told The World that the upcoming COP30 is a chance for countries to advance the current agenda and create greater climate targets.   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Russia deploys 100,000 troops to capture Ukraine's Pokrovsk city | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Intense fighting is continuing in and around the city of Pokrovsk in eastern Ukraine's Donetsk region, with Moscow deploying around 100,000 troops into battle in a bid to capture the strategic centre. Pokrovsk is considered a key logistics hub and military supply route in eastern Ukraine, and Russia has long seen it as a vital gateway to taking the rest of the Donetsk region. The Ukrainian army said its units were battling hard to try to stop the Russians from gaining new ground, but has acknowledged that its troops face a difficult fight. Ukraine-based journalist, Emmanuelle Chaze spoke with The World's Girish Sawlani about the latest developments.    Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Are AI stocks a bubble ready to burst? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: We want to hear from you! Please complete our survey: 2025 ABC News Daily Audience Survey (https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=mkDBl3hw50e7lNHlNQPgEpOxE0YscZ5Au4rK0pnU0zpURUxPU0ZaM0g0M1NaSEg4QVFVUFFKMVc4Uy4u)    Chip making giant Nvidia’s value hit $5 trillion US last week, a milestone that just a few years ago was unthinkable.   Two other tech giants have hit the $4 trillion US mark as excitement about the promise of AI drives investor interest.    But in an uncertain world are the sky-high valuations sustainable, or a bubble that will soon bust?    Today, the ABC’s chief business correspondent Ian Verrender on why this might not be a bubble that bursts like the dot-com crash of the early-2000s.    Featured:    Ian Verrender, ABC Chief Business Correspondent

title: Will the Israeli military's 'Yellow Line' keep Gaza split in two? | ABC NEWS
description: Many Palestinians are unable to return to their homes in Gaza, a month after the ceasefire came into effect. As part of the first phase of the US-brokered deal, the Israeli military has withdrawn to what's known as the 'Yellow Line,' but it still controls about half of the strip. With no clear time frame on the next stage of the withdrawal process, many residents fear the territory will remain split. title: Muswellbrook endorses ban on temporary donga accomodation | ABC News
description: The NSW coal town of Muswellbrook will require renewable projects to build permanent accommodation in town, banning 'donga-style' workers camps. The villages could then be reused as affordable housing, which locals say is desperately needed.
